awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Fundamentals of Low-complexity Relaxations for Nonconvex Optimization Problems with Conic Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant will pioneer novel tools for the analysis and design of efficient and scalable algorithms for solving large-scale nonconvex optimization problems with conic constraints. These problems are critical components of operational problems in many diverse fields facing uncertainty such as energy, finance, and telemedicine, and are also  frequently used in extracting useful information from high-dimensional data. While convex conic optimization problems are efficiently solvable, the presence of nonconvexities, such as yes/no decisions, present significant new challenges and the state-of-the-art algorithms do not scale well. This award supports foundational research to establish frameworks that overcome these challenges by exploiting valuable structural information in a unified manner. The main developments will address key trade-offs on relaxation quality and computational tractability. If successful, these developments will advance the fundamental tool set in optimization, thus improving the efficiency of operations in a broad range of activities in the aforementioned sectors, having a profound impact on US economy and society. Progress in this vein will provide valuable insights to researchers and practitioners in interdisciplinary domains such as machine learning and high dimensional statistics. The outcomes of this research will be incorporated into commonly used open-source platforms and integrated into the graduate curriculum. These efforts will also go hand-in-hand with synergistic activities to promote operations research among underrepresented groups as well as encourage creative mathematical problem solving skills in K-12 education. 

This award aims to develop foundational theory to study the key properties of structured non-convex sets and design new efficient algorithms. The focus will be on development of new systemic techniques to generate classes of low-complexity relaxations (expressed in linear or conic form) that are effective and easy to incorporate into existing and/or novel algorithmic frameworks. This research will introduce non-traditional paradigms for incorporating more information into the convexification process from different types of cones, multiple conic structures simultaneously present, and specific sources of nonconvexities such as nonconvex quadratics. Degradation of relaxation quality due to partial information use and resulting computational complexity trade-offs will be rigorously quantified. Whenever possible, these developments will be supplemented with explicit results on convex hull characterizations and accompanied with efficient algorithms based on reduced-complexity optimization methods to further enhance the scalability of this approach. Research findings will be studied in a diverse set of models from a number of interdisciplinary fields

por.por_cntn:
Non-convex optimization problems with conic constraints arise ubiquitously in applications ranging from decision making in several sectors such as finance and energy that invariably operate under uncertain environments to extracting useful information from high-dimensional data in the context of machine learning and statistics. Due to their nonconvexities and large scale, the resulting problems face substantial computational challenges. The principal goal of this project was to advance our fundamental toolset to solve such problems. We focused on four broad objectives: i) develop low-complexity convex reformulations or high-quality relaxations of certain key structures in these problems, ii) investigate exactness guarantees offered by the well-known convex relaxations, iii) exploit the resulting structural results in guiding the design of algorithmic features that effectively trade-off relaxation quality and computational tractability, and iv) support the training of new researchers, integrate the research output into graduate curriculum, and increase the societal impact through outreach programs.

 

One of the main contributions of this project is the development of new systemic techniques to generate and analyze the strength of classes of valid inequalities (in linear or conic form) that are effective and easy to incorporate into existing algorithmic frameworks. To this end, we studied a fundamental structure in mixed integer conic programs (MICPs), namely the disjunctive conic sets and developed a mathematical theory for identifying features of strong valid linear inequalities for them. Crucially, and also in contrast to the prior literature, our theory was based on the notion of conic-minimality which allowed us to utilize the vital information encoded in the convex relaxation of the problem. We utilized these insights in derivation of explicit closed-form expressions of convex and conic inequalities that fully describe the convex hull of specific disjunctive conic sets?a two-term linear disjunction applied to the second-order cone or the positive semidefinite cone. These characterizations provide fundamental insights into the development of new and efficient general-purpose cutting-surface schemes for MICPs.

 

Another major contribution of this work is the advancement of our understanding of a standard tool for nonconvex Quadratically Constrained Quadratic Programs (QCQPs), namely the semidefinite programming (SDP) relaxations. In this project, we examined questions surrounding SDP exactness from various angles. In particular, we established sufficient conditions for i) the convex hull of a QCQP to be given by the projection of the convex hull of its SDP relaxation onto the original space, ii) the optimum objective value of the SDP relaxation to match the optimum objective value of the QCQP, and iii) the SDP feasible region to be rank-one generated. We further accompanied these results with examples illustrating the almost necessity of the requirements in the aforementioned sufficient conditions. Collectively, this research is a significant step towards developing a general theory for SDP exactness and has the potential of significant impact in many application areas.

 

As another significant contribution of this project, we established low-complexity convex reformulations of the trust region subproblem (TRS), its variants and its generalization. TRS is an essential component of generic nonlinear programming solvers and thus a part of the primary toolkit of many optimization users. As opposed to the standard SDP based reformulations, our reformulations are given by convex quadratic programs. Moreover, based on these reformulations, we offered methodologies to solve TRS and generalized TRS that guarantee a theoretical linear-time (in terms of the number of nonzero entries in the input data) convergence rate establishing the current state-of-the-art.

 

Results from this project have also been instrumental in the design of principled frameworks for directly handling optimization problems with data uncertainties and dynamic nature. Based on first-order methods, we developed principled meta-frameworks, equipped with theoretical guarantees, that trade high accuracy for computational efficiency gains in solving various fundamental optimization under uncertainty paradigms, including robust convex optimization and joint estimation-optimization problems.  To enable better and seamless integration of predictive models within optimization, we investigated the joint performance of prediction and optimization models from an end-to-end point of view and developed novel models and efficient methodologies for learning from revealed preferences in dynamic environments.

 

In addition to advancing the theoretical and algorithmic foundation in optimization, the PI has strived to have a positive impact at various other levels in this project including: i) the training of graduate and undergraduate students in research supporting the primary step in creating a sustainable cycle of research and its dissemination to practice, ii) the design and delivery of a new graduate course integrating research outcomes from this project into curriculum, iii) outreach and mentorship activities and spearheading and supporting programs to advocate the usefulness of operations research techniques on society as well as promoting interest in STEM fields to women and underrepresented minorities.
